importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Arye Zalmanovich is believed to have been killed in captivity on this date, marking the end of his life and making him the oldest hostage taken by Hamas.
Tamir Adar died defending Kibbutz Nir Oz on this date during the initial Hamas attack, and his body was taken to Gaza, which is central to the context of hostage recovery efforts.
The US-proposed ceasefire deal was signed on this date, setting a timeline for Hamas to return hostages, including the deceased, and triggering the current phase of hostage recovery.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Under the Trump administration ceasefire agreement, Hamas was required to return all deceased hostages within the first 72 hours of the ceasefire going into effect.

The return of deceased hostages is an ongoing effort, with Hamas facing challenges in recovering bodies buried under rubble or otherwise inaccessible, and the process is described as not happening overnight.

keyTakeAways: Arye Zalmanovich, 85, was the oldest hostage taken by Hamas following the October 7, 2023 attacks and is believed to have been killed in captivity on November 17, 2023.
Tamir Adar, 38, died defending Kibbutz Nir Oz on October 7, 2023, and his body was taken to Gaza; he is now among the deceased returned to Israel.
The two bodies were returned to Israel on October 21, 2025, and are being identified at the National Institute for Forensic Medicine.
These are the 14th and 15th deceased hostages to be transferred since the ceasefire deal was signed on October 9, 2025.

Hamas has stated that significant efforts and special equipment are needed to recover bodies in Gaza, and one previously returned body was misidentified, suggesting possible challenges in identification and retrieval.

The US vice president, JD Vance, visited Israel and emphasized the importance of returning bodies to families, noting that recovery is difficult and will take time, especially due to rubble and unknown locations.
Israel and Hamas have each accused the other of ceasefire violations, contributing to ongoing tensions and uncertainty in the implementation of the agreement.
The IDF has requested public sensitivity and patience, as official identification of the deceased is still pending and crucial for families.

namedEntities.name: Arye Zalmanovich
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Israeli civilian and former kibbutz founder, aged 85, abducted by Hamas on October 7, 2023, believed to have been killed in captivity on November 17, 2023.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the oldest hostage taken by Hamas, making his case a symbol of the extreme age and vulnerability of hostages, and a focal point for discussions on human rights, captivity, and the personal loss experienced by families.

namedEntities.name: Tamir Adar
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Israeli civilian from Kibbutz Nir Oz, 38, who died defending his community on October 7, 2023, and whose body was taken to Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He represents the tragic loss of young lives during the initial Hamas attack and underscores the ongoing struggle to recover and return deceased Israeli citizens from Gaza.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Palestinian militant group responsible for the October 7, 2023 attacks and currently responsible for holding hostages and recovering bodies in Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas is central to the narrative as the entity that both took hostages and is now obligated to return them under the ceasefire agreement, with ongoing challenges in recovery and identification.

namedEntities.name: Israel Defense Forces (IDF)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Israeli military responsible for responding to Hamas attacks, managing the recovery of hostages, and enforcing the ceasefire agreement.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The IDF is directly involved in identifying bodies, verifying the deceased, and asserting that Hamas must uphold its obligations under the ceasefire deal.

namedEntities.name: Trump administration
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The U.S. government under President Donald Trump, which proposed the ceasefire agreement and is now moving to implement its next phase.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Trump administration's ceasefire plan provides the legal and diplomatic framework for hostage return and has been a major point of international involvement in the conflict.

namedEntities.name: JD Vance
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. Vice President, who visited Israel and spoke publicly about the return of deceased hostages.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His visit and statements reinforce international pressure on Hamas to return bodies and emphasize the humanitarian imperative behind the recovery effort.

namedEntities.name: Kibbutz Nir Oz
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A kibbutz in southern Israel where both Arye Zalmanovich and Tamir Adar were based and where the Hamas attack occurred.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is a location central to the events of October 7, 2023, and a symbolic site of both victimization and community resilience.

namedEntities.name: National Institute for Forensic Medicine
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli institution responsible for identifying the deceased and investigating causes of death.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the site where the two bodies are being officially identified, marking a critical step in the legal and emotional closure for families.

namedEntities.name: Ceasefire deal
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A US-proposed agreement between Israel and Hamas signed on October 9, 2025, requiring Hamas to return all living and deceased hostages.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It sets the framework for hostage return, including a requirement for Hamas to deliver deceased hostages within 72 hours, and remains a key point of diplomatic and humanitarian concern.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The oldest hostage taken by Hamas following the October 7, 2023 attacks, Arye Zalmanovich, aged 85, is among the two deceased hostages returned to Israel on October 21, 2025. His death in captivity on November 17, 2023, makes him a symbol of the extreme age and vulnerability of hostages. Tamir Adar, a 38-year-old defender of Kibbutz Nir Oz who died on October 7, 2023, is also among the returned remains. However, Hamas has stated that significant efforts and equipment are needed to recover bodies buried under rubble, and one previously returned body was misidentified. title: Oldest hostage held by Hamas among two deceased returned to Israel Tuesday
